text: Do any of you guys in here who are profitable do this exclusively, or do you keep down the day job too? I ask obviously as automation does not require the same amounts of screen time that manual trading does.

elements.text: Do any of you guys in here who are profitable do this exclusively, or do you keep down the day job too? I ask obviously as automation does not require the same amounts of screen time that manual trading does.

text: There are a mix here. I do it full time

elements.text: There are a mix here. I do it full time

text: I keep a day job. It's good to diversify income streams, and what I do could easily stop working if market characteristics changed.

elements.text: I keep a day job. It's good to diversify income streams, and what I do could easily stop working if market characteristics changed.

text: Also, having a day job provides NI contributions, which means I'll get a pension when I hit state retirement age.

elements.text: Also, having a day job provides NI contributions, which means I'll get a pension when I hit state retirement age.

text: I've just taken early, semi-retirement, which basically means I will continue to do odd-jobs here and there.  Having 40 years software development experience means I'm no spring chicken but I do "get" how to develop software for the finance industry in the manner to which they subscribe (long story).  So now, I finally have the time to get stuck into my BF trading bots and I'm "quietly confident" (yes, I understand the irony of being "quiet" whilst announcing my plans").  Anyway, as I've stated in my profile, in theory, I'm happy to consider various collaborations if anyone has a decent idea or maybe something else.  The only potential sticking point is that I am a 100% Microsoft "stack" developer.  Although, I'm seeing Python associated with so many articles to do with modelling, AI and ML, etc., that I MAY be tempted to have a look into the language soon!

text: Do many people here use AI/ML successfully? From my experience of traders, the higher the IQ, the lower the returns.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Do many people here use AI/ML successfully? From my experience of traders, the higher the IQ, the lower the returns.

text: I have recently started to look into AI & ML, purely from the perspective of C# though.  So far, there appears to be quite a lot of useful information available and I'm hopeful of using ML to help me identify patterns, which I may not have been aware of otherwise.  Also interested to the experience of others

text: I hope you find something useful to you. I have quite a jaded view, as all the truly effective strategies that I have seen, are the result of human intuition/skills/observation. Not AI/ML models. If you look at the public returns of hedge funds that claim a  heavy use of AI/ML, the real returns don't match the bluster of the promotional material.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I hope you find something useful to you. I have quite a jaded view, as all the truly effective strategies that I have seen, are the result of human intuition/skills/observation. text:
I’ve developed software for various hedge-funds over the years, as well as a few private funds, who share with hedge funds, the advantage of being able to trade pretty much any asset class they like.

Obviously, I can’t comment on specific details and I don’t claim to offer my opinions on ALL hedge funds, but I can tell you that as for the places I’ve worked at, they will try pretty much anything once!  They’ll use whatever technology, information or skills are at their disposal.

Again, in my experience only, my perception of these funds and the people who run/own them is that they will go to extraordinary lengths to squeeze that extra penny from their trades and positions and very often, they won’t even blink at throwing a LOT of money at something if they believe it will improve their bottom line.

Also (and I can’t say too much on this subject), I wouldn’t believe EVERYTHING that’s published publicly by the hedge funds, especially regarding their EXACT returns, etc.  There are thousands of techniques and tricks, which can be used to skew their numbers if that’s what is needed at that time.  Nuff said.

As for ML, I wouldn’t say I’m sceptical, yet, as I need to fully immerse myself in the subject and give it the benefit of the doubt regarding my specific needs.  I’ve been around long enough to see all manner of trends come and go but somehow, I think ML will be around for a while yet.  Even if it turns out to have no value for trading, etc., I believe it’s proven itself enough in other domains already to warrant the attention it’s receiving now.

Also (and I can’t say too much on this subject), I wouldn’t believe EVERYTHING that’s published publicly by the hedge funds, especially regarding their EXACT returns, etc.  There are thousands of techniques and tricks, which can be used to skew their numbers if that’s what is needed at that time.  Nuff said.

As for ML, I wouldn’t say I’m sceptical, yet, as I need to fully immerse myself in the subject and give it the benefit of the doubt regarding my specific needs.  I’ve been around long enough to see all manner of trends come and go but somehow, I think ML will be around for a while yet.  Even if it turns out to have no value for trading, etc., I believe it’s proven itself enough in other domains already to warrant the attention it’s receiving now.

text:
Hey All

Complete newbie to Betfair, dont know any programming I just work in construction finance.

Would anyone be open to helping our punters get up and running on Betfair? - currently we bet via bookies only.

We are trying to setup database or excel of previous results for horse racing / grey hound racing including opening prices & prices at jump, summarised by jockeys / trainers etc.

Is anyone open to assisting? If so, could you please advise rates? 

Look forward to hearing from you all!

Cheers
